Expectation1: Help out during difficult times or emergencies.
Situation1: A I04iend on their way to the airport calls, thinking they left their passport at home, and asks if you can check and bring it to them right away.
Situation2: An irate long-time customer challenges the legitimacy of the offer and demands thorough explanations.
Story:
My phone buzzed just as I was about to dial the next number on my call list. It was Sam, my oldest friend, his voice tight with panic. “I think I left my passport at home. Can you check and bring it to the airport? My flight’s in two hours.” I could hear the desperation in his voice, and I knew how much this trip meant to him. But as I promised to check, my headset crackled—my supervisor was listening in, and I was already behind on my calls. 

I forced a smile and launched into my next pitch, only to be met with a furious customer. “How do I know this isn’t a scam? Explain every detail!” he barked. My training told me to stay calm, answer every question, and not let the call end badly. But my mind kept drifting to Sam, picturing him frantically searching his bags at the airport. My hands shook as I tried to juggle the customer’s demands and the urgent texts from Sam. I felt torn in two, the weight of both expectations pressing down, unsure which role I was about to let down.
